results.notes:
Growing in a primarily live oak(Quercus agrifolia) habitat with perhaps a fir nearby.
Spore print white.
Spores ~ 8.5-11.0 X 6.8-8.0 microns, broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid.
Q(range) = 1.21-1.38
Q(avg) = 1.30 n=20
I assumed these were our typical local Oak Chanterelles(C. californicus), but the spore color(white vs creamy to light yellow) and spore width(6.8-8.0 vs 4-5.5 microns) doesn’t quite fit(?). Doesn’t fit C. formosus either.
Questions remain.

results.notes:
Location approximate

The small size, association with hardwoods in eastern North America, and drab coloration point to the Laccaria laccata complex. According to MushroomExpert.com, the caps of L. tortilis have vinaceous tones that other species in this complex lack. Vinaceous tones and very small size suggests that this observation could be L. tortilis. However, this species seems to typically have a more contorted cap with irregularly wavy, striate margins. The caps here aren’t particularly wavy and aren’t striate. For comparison, L. ohiensis also seems to have a more striate cap, So L. laccata might be the safest bet here. Although, I’m unsure whether or not these species can be reliably differentiated without microscopy.

results.notes:
There are certainly multiple caloplaca species in this observation, so I probably will break this up into multiple observations in the future and add a few pictures. The genus is abundant here with large, colorful swaths of it amassing into lichen “rainbows” on the rocks.
this may be ignea, but it would be taller -lobed and more purple than I have encountered (update: the purple color is fine for ignea. I don’t know what to make of the lobe height though)

The pastel peach, pink and yellow thalli I was thinking were a variant of impolita, but some of the lobes are very broad, so perhaps they are approaching star-shaped?
There is also at least one species of Caloplaca in here that lacks outer lobes.
Saxicola is also very common at this site, but as far as I can tell, that species is probably not in this picture. Again, I could be wrong. Any opinions or information welcome.

results.notes:
Mild russulas with yellow spores under Douglas-fir and Monterey Pine.
Gills creamy yellow becoming straw color to medium yellow, crowded. Disc a dark smudge around the center of the purple cap, usually with small yellow dots nearby. Lighter and finely striated margin. Cap becoming bowl shaped to a degree, with skin peeling at least a third the distance to the center. Viscid when moist, at least in the center, but becoming dry and smooth.
Stipe clean white, unblemishing but with fine white striations.
Spores roughly 7x 8.5-9 micros, long lines/ridges, partial reticulum, elliptical
Distinct chemical odor was present at the lower portion of the stipe and not elsewhere. This was checked carefully several times. The scent was not unpleasant or overpowering. I have not smelled iodine/iodoform for a while, but could have been similar.
Perhaps because of their condition, mushrooms broke apart quite easily.

results.notes:
Microscopy and ID by Django Grootmyers.
Dimitic. Skeletal hyphae brown. Generative hyphae seemed mostly simple septate. Setae were present but concentrated in patches in the brown areas. The gray areas had far fewer setae. Basidia 4-spored. Spores hyaline, allantoid and smooth. Hyphidia present but not branched — some curved. This seems to be a decent match for H. curtisii microscopically but I couldn’t find mention of the contrasting gray and brown areas in the literature on that species.

results.notes:
Growing in an area with spread wood chips. Tree closest to the mushrooms was black gum (Nyssa sylvatica), oak about 10 yards away.

Mushroom with blue bruising on the tubes was likely damaged in-situ by a grass-cutting crew.

Ribbed stipe surface and bright yellow young pores remind me of X. subtomentosus. But the caps appear to be glabrous, and the blue bruising on the damaged pores is intense for subtomentosus.

6th photo… the stipe appears to lack ornamentation (at least to the extent of the others), but otherwise looks to be the same type; found in the same wood chip area. May be the same mushroom as the one seen in the 4th photo down. Last photo… stipe ornamentation raised threadlike.

Cap widths 1"-3".

results.notes:
If it’s what we think it is, this charismatic collection represents a new club record for both Alley Pond Park and the overall NYC species list. A second and quite different tiny asco was found occurring on another seedpod collected immediately adjacent to this one, but it has not yet been photographed or scoped. Limited literature resources (as in not having the powdery mildew bible on hand) made a species ID difficult to claim with certainty, but E. liriodendri was collected by Peck1, and is characterized by an abundance of superficial, mycelium in which the cleistothecia are partly to fully embedded.

1 Ellis, JB; Everhart, BM. 1892. The North American Pyrenomycetes. :1-793

results.notes:
It had been three and a half years since I’d last (and first) seen Merismodes in person (Observation 191343). After Juniper Perlis showed me what to look for on our walk in Latourette Park, I had the gestalt down and started seeing it again and again (it’s smaller than I remembered, but smaller still in the cold and dry of the winter with the cups all closed). While it might be regionally rare elsewhere in New York, it is locally abundant all over NYC. What no one expected to find the next day was M. fasciculata; one of M. anomala’s macroscopically indistinguishable sister species. Tom scoped this one and found the characteristic differences in hair ornamentation and spore size to clinch the ID, making this a first for both Alley Pond Park and the overall NYC list.

results.notes:
Microscopy and ID by Django Grootmeyers.
Growing on the underside of well-rotted hardwood log. Subiculum not blue or green in KOH. Spores brownish, seemingly dichotomously warted and not becoming blue in KOH. All parts inamyloid. Dimitic with skeletal hyphae seemingly only present in the subiculum. Subicular generative hyphae brown and clamped – unambiguous clamps lacking in all other generative hyphae. Generative hyphae (not subicular) measured at 6.1, 5.4 and 7.8 µm. Basidia 4-sterigmate, some brownish, without clamps. Did not notice any chlamydospores but may have overlooked them. Cytisida absent.

Individual sterigmata: 6.9, 9.1, 5.4, 5.1, 5.7 µm

Growing on the underside of a California bay laurel branch, 2.5 cm thick. Covering area of 8 × 2 cm. Soft, gelatinous.

Spores 5.5-7 × 2-2.5, wiith clamped base. Monomitic, hyphae 3 microns wide, with clamps. Basidia typically 40-47 × 6-7, much longer than the 30 microns upper bound in the common species (Ph. radiata, rufa, acerina). results.notes:
This is the first ever documented occurrence of Psilocybe Cubensis in Zimbabwe.

Robert van der Horst discovered Psilocybe Cubensis Imire / Psilocybe Cubensis Zimbabwe on March 8th, 2018 at Imire Rhino & Wildlife Conservancy in the Wedza district of Mashonaland East province approx. 120km south-east of Harare, Zimbabwe.
Between March 8th, 2018 and March 17th, 2018, I (Robert van der Horst) have personally collected over 50 Psilocybe Cubensis Imire / Zimbabwe mushrooms in this area.

It has been positively ID’d by several “Trusted Identifiers” here on shroomery plus several mycologists have also positively ID’d it as P. Cubensis.

Psilocybin-containing mushrooms were previously thought to be almost non-existent in southern Africa. The last collected specimen of a psilocybe mushroom was in South Africa many years ago.

I have taken spore prints of many of the mushrooms. If you are interested in obtaining a spore print (for mycology purposes), please send me a message.
results.location_name: Wedza, Zimbabwe

results.notes:
Thinking about how Gary Lincoff used to pitch hunting for “black spots on sticks” (when conditions for macro-fungi seemed dubious). Set out yesterday in hopes of bringing some in… and lo and behold! Here they are.

On a fallen beech branch, likely from a tree that had toppled a few years back.

Scraped some off the stick, tried to crush the material for scoping at 400×. Mounted in 4% KOH, then Meltzer’s. Second photo (KOH) shows an inflated projection that may be an ascus (my best guess). Third photo (KOH) shows two more-or-less elliptical objects that I think may be mature spores, roughly 32-36 × 11-16 microns. I found a fair number of these, and shape/size variation similar to the two seen in the 3rd photo down. Fourth photo (Meltzer’s) shows a cluster of globose objects that appear to exhibit a dextrinoid reaction (not sure, may just be the color of the Meltzer’s). I didn’t find any other such structures in subsequent microscopy, so maybe this is the substrate (wood/bark).
results.location_name: Susquehanna Riverlands, Salem Twp., Luzerne Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:

Pigment extracted in KOH orangish to reddish-brown.

Seems to match well with H. fragiforme, although this is a European species name. Found no info on the possibility of an alternative NA name. Looks like lot’s of species in this genus, though. AF of NA includes a few species for genus Annulohypoxylon. No idea about the difference between genera H and A… if there is any.

Tiny white crusty things adhered to the surfaces… something else? (Zoom second photo.)

results.notes:
On bark of Juniperus californica along Santa Barbara Canyon Road, south of Cuyama Valley. Two collections included in photos below, showing variation in pruina on apothecial disks.

Thallus thin, greenish brown, occurring around base of apothecia. Apothecia <0.5mm, plane, often flexuous, with a dark maroonish disk with light to heavy white pruina, and white pruinose, persistently raised thalline margin that is at times slightly cracked or dentate (not as much as L. crenulata). Epihymenium brown with few POL+ crystals insoluble in K. Amphithecium present, with algae, lacking or very thin cortex with medium sized POL+ crystals in the outer cortex layer, not within the amphithecium, that are insoluble in K. Hymenium hyaline, lacking POL+ “dispersa-type” granules. Algae thick across base of apothecia.

Spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. Average 12.3×5.9 (n=9).

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1116/2018_DSC1268

Habitat: Slightly inclined mountain slope, south aspect; a patch of stony grassland surrounded by trees and bushes (former pastures), Ostrya carpinifolia and Corylus avellana dominant; calcareous, skeletal, colluvial ground; full sun, relatively warm, dry and open place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 615 m (2.020 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: on thallus and podetia of Cladonia cf. pocillum, soil and mosses.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, Na melu place near Strgulc, Soča 46 abandoned farm house, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Diploschistes muscorum is an interesting, cosmopolitan lichen living on ground. When young it parasitizes other lichens of Cladonia pyxidata group (Wirth 1995), especially Cladonia rangiformis and Cladonia pocillum (Dobson 2005). In this observation the host seems to be Cladonia pocillum. It gradually incorporates the algae of the host in its own thallus (Brodo 2001) and thus kill it. When mature it becomes free-living on mosses and ground without help of parasitism. It can grow to considerable sizes. This observation shows small, young specimens, max a few cm in diameter. Picture 3 shows a young specimen just becoming fertile, where lowest, outer squamules of the host are still alive and green. Picture 5c shows a podetium of the host thinly overgrown with Diploschistes muscorum thallus. Picture 2 shows an older specimen where no parts of the host can be seen directly, however, the shape of the thallus still resembles to some extent original shape of the Cladonia squamules. Later there is no more resemblance on Cladonia.

Growing scattered. Several specimens found in the vicinity. Photographed in damp conditions.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70 mm/f4

results.notes: I don’t know how Fungi Bartl. became the name in my posts, but it wasn’t intended. This is a side view of a piece I took from the edge of the fruiting body. I’m sure this is a rare polypore. The rim extends vertically away from the tree and has rings from the previous year’s growth. As you can see, it is very woody and solid like a chunk of wood. Please see my other observation images for the entire mushroom. I have had this piece in storage for about 1.5 months at 38 degree F. Has very aggressive mycelium and is growing all over the specimen even at this low temp. Hope this picture helps shed light on my first observation.

results.notes:
On old wood boards in a semi-arid grassland/shrubland setting in Cuyama Valley.

Thallus thin, lumpy, greenish grey, beneath and around apothecia. Apothecia about 0.2mm, crowded, becoming convex and misshapen. Disk maroon, epruinose, darkening, roughened, matte. Margin weak, concolorous with grey thallus or lighter tan, appearing ragged and lacking cortex at 20×. Epihymenium reddish brown with KOH soluble POL+ orange crystals extending into hymenium. Amphithecium weakly developed, with POL+ small crystals soluble in K.

Spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. Average size 9.8×5.2 (n=4).

Not sure what species this is, I thought something in the L. saligna group, but I need to spend some more time reviewing the literature.
